stream_context.summary: Kaze iterates on a scripted-yet-physics-inspired paper airplane flight mechanic used to reach a pyramid, debugs instability caused by a bad/uninitialized variable, and completes the associated “target mission.” He also shows off recent N64-specific rendering/performance fixes for the demo (AA toggle, coverage/alpha artifact removal, HUD correctness), adds/validates a Toad-like NPC that dispenses a star, and prototypes/repairs a rubber-band slingshot animation pipeline in Blender/Fast64 (discovering an export quirk that dropped the first frame).
stream_context.significance_reason: He declares the paper airplane feature “done” (completing the target mission), shows the demo as “all done” with multiple N64 bug fixes, and establishes a workable workflow for rubber-band animation after diagnosing an export-frame issue.

findings.summary: A major cause of the paper airplane instability was an uninitialized/random stack value being used in the physics code; fixing it immediately made the behavior more coherent.

Kaze explicitly prefers a physically-motivated (even if heavily “fudged”) flight model over a fully precomputed spline path, because he wants a physical basis for the motion and to avoid adding/maintaining spline tooling.
findings.quote: Of course, I can just put it on a spline, but then I just have to add a spline… I prefer [computations], because there’s some kind of physical basis for it.

findings.summary: The desired paper airplane feel is a repeated “swoop/swoop” wave with regained speed—interesting, slightly chaotic, and not a straight line—while still reliably landing on/into the pyramid where it should stop on contact.
findings.quote: We want it to move like a real paper plane… we want it to go swoop, swoop… and… as soon as you touch the pyramid, it stops there.

findings.summary: To stabilize and shape the plane’s oscillation, he experiments with clamping pitch ranges, making pitch acceleration depend on face angle pitch (rather than only velocity), and adds friction/resistance to avoid runaway rotation while retaining controlled chaos.

Kaze’s stream dynamic includes pushing back hard when chat asks rapid-fire implementation questions during early prototyping; he frames the work as iterative tuning where answers will emerge after the system exists.
findings.quote: The answer to every single one of your questions so far is just shut up and wait.

findings.summary: He finishes the paper targets off-stream: Mario can break them by colliding ("with Mario’s face"), though they still need an animation; he considers this completion enough to call the paper airplane/target mission finished.
findings.quote: I finished programming the paper targets off stream… They still need an animation… Either way, the Paper Airplane is done. That finishes the target mission.

findings.summary: He discovers a reproducible cannon-related bug: pressing A immediately on the first frame after exiting a cannon causes a bug; waiting even briefly avoids it.
findings.quote: Immediately pressing A out of a cannon leads to a bug… Pressing A on the first frame bugs me.

findings.summary: Kaze states the demo is “all done” and claims he fixed all N64 bugs he was tracking, with final console testing still pending (he plans a playthrough-style verification).
findings.quote: The demo is all done, by the way. I fixed all the N64 bugs… I have not fully tested the demo on console yet.

findings.summary: N64 rendering/performance improvements shown: anti-aliasing can be toggled off for a big FPS increase (~50 FPS in a shown area), and a prior artifact (a visible line) was fixed by addressing a coverage*alpha interaction; HUD presentation on N64 is shown and called “beautiful.”

Texture flicker/offset issues in a “retro world” segment are identified as emulator (Glide) bugs rather than N64 behavior; mipmapping is framed as the real solution for distance flicker, not anti-aliasing.
findings.quote: The offset textures are Glide bug… Mipmap is the only thing that works.

findings.summary: Fast64 currently limits mipmap level support (two levels), and adding more would require manually writing display lists—work Kaze avoids because it would complicate iteration (re-insertion after each export).

He contextualizes larger engine evolution: F3DEX3 is now in the project, improving performance (triangle strips/fans/occlusion-plane-related changes), but also shifting bottlenecks—his current build is RSP-bottlenecked.
The Course 14 stage is described as multi-biome (desert with pyramid, mountains with “styrofoam,” a castle area, and grasslands), and a tentative working title is floated (“Handmade Heights”).
Zeina briefly joins mid-stream as Kaze demonstrates progress; Kaze notes he’s not the project’s animator and is mainly producing a workable base for others to refine.
findings.quote: It’s technically fine because I’m not the animator for this game anyway. Really, I just need a decent base so that we can make this work.

findings.summary: A rubber-band slingshot animation export issue is traced to a “smart animation range” behavior that trimmed away the first frame because there was no keyframe before frame 1; adding an earlier keyframe restores proper timing.
findings.quote: The first animation frame wasn’t exporting because there’s a smart animation range feature… it just cut the first frame.

zeina.summary: Zeina appears briefly and asks what’s happening; Kaze uses the moment to showcase completed paper airplane work and mentions remaining work on the slingshot to fling Mario.

findings.summary: Lilaa is referenced jokingly during the rubber-band animation debugging segment (no concrete dev contribution mentioned in this transcript).

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I thought what made you insane when you romhack is the romhacking itself. But no, it’s Twitch chat like watching you romhack.
memorable_quotes.context: Frustration/comedy beat while chat questions pile up during paper airplane physics tuning.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: Of course, I can just put it on a spline, but… I prefer [doing] these computations… there’s some kind of physical basis for it.
memorable_quotes.context: Explains why he’s building a “physics-ish” system rather than a fully scripted flight path.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I think the bar for 3D platformers is so incredibly low that making a 3D platformer is easy at this point.
memorable_quotes.context: Broader design/business philosophy about why a solid, non-bad platformer can stand out today.

key_stories.title: Paper airplane mechanic: from chaos to controllable swoops
key_stories.summary: Kaze builds a paper airplane flight behavior intended to oscillate (“swoop/swoop”) and land onto a pyramid as a traversal tool. Early attempts produce runaway rotation, wrong velocity recovery, and inconsistent tipping behavior.
key_stories.challenge: Creating motion that feels paper-plane-like (chaotic but readable) while still being reliable enough for platforming and landing precisely at a pyramid target.
key_stories.process: He iterates on equations tying pitch to forward velocity/face angle pitch, adds friction/resistance, clamps pitch ranges, and repeatedly tunes constants. He also chooses a physically-motivated simulation instead of a precomputed spline to preserve a ‘real’ basis for motion.
key_stories.outcome: He reaches a flight pattern he calls “good shit,” then adjusts landing position and stop-on-contact behavior, and ultimately declares the paper airplane complete for the target mission.
key_stories.key_quote: We just kind of need to fudge the equations in a way that we get the result we want.

key_stories.title: Hidden root cause: random stack value breaks the plane physics
key_stories.summary: After prolonged instability, Kaze identifies that a value used by the system wasn’t initialized and was effectively random. Correcting it immediately improves behavior and makes subsequent tuning meaningful.
key_stories.challenge: Unpredictable, irreproducible-feeling behavior during physics tuning.
key_stories.process: He investigates variable behavior and recognizes a stack garbage value (“random value on stack”) was being read and applied.
key_stories.outcome: System becomes more stable/understandable, enabling progress to a ‘good base’ flight model.
key_stories.key_quote: It was a random value on stack that we used.

key_stories.title: Demo polish on real hardware: AA toggle and coverage/alpha artifact fix
key_stories.summary: Kaze shows N64 demo improvements: correct anti-aliasing options, a large FPS boost when AA is off, and removal of a visible line artifact traced to coverage multiplied by alpha. He also highlights HUD correctness on console.
key_stories.challenge: Hardware-accurate rendering issues and performance constraints on N64.
key_stories.process: He implements AA toggles, tracks down a coverage/alpha interaction causing visual seams/lines, and validates output on N64 while noting remaining z-order issues.
key_stories.outcome: He calls the demo “all done” with N64 bugs fixed, pending full playthrough testing on console.

key_stories.title: Rubber-band slingshot animation pipeline breaks due to trimmed first frame
key_stories.summary: While animating the rubber bands in Blender/Fast64, Kaze sees timing/pose issues and realizes the exported animation effectively starts late. The cause is an export feature that trims frames until the first keyed frame—cutting frame 1 when there’s no earlier keyframe.
key_stories.challenge: Mismatch between intended rubber-band motion (snap forward then fling back) and what appears in-game.
key_stories.process: He diagnoses the export behavior (“smart animation range”), adds a keyframe before the first frame to prevent trimming, and retests the animation timing.
key_stories.outcome: Rubber-band animation becomes smooth and usable as a base for final polish (sound effects still needed).
key_stories.key_quote: The first animation frame wasn’t exporting… because I didn’t have a keyframe before the first frame.

key_stories.title: A cannon edge-case bug becomes a known constraint
key_stories.summary: While testing the airplane/cannon interaction, Kaze finds that pressing A immediately on the first frame after firing causes a bug; delaying input avoids it. He recognizes it as a recurring issue he’s encountered before.
key_stories.challenge: Input timing causing a reproducible bug at the exact moment of cannon exit.
key_stories.process: He intentionally re-tests the ‘press immediately’ case, compares it to ‘press nothing,’ and isolates the trigger as the first (or first two) frames.
key_stories.outcome: Bug is documented as a known edge case to handle or design around.
key_stories.key_quote: It’s only there if you press it on the first frame.

open_questions.topic: Paper airplane ‘physics-ish’ design vs scripted path
open_questions.context: Kaze prefers computed motion over splines but still ‘fudges’ constants heavily to achieve a fun wave-like swoop while landing reliably on the pyramid.
questions: What was the initial design target for the airplane (player fantasy + gameplay purpose) and how did it evolve during prototyping?
Where did you draw the line between ‘realistic enough’ and ‘fun/readable’ for platforming?
Did you consider giving the player steering control, and why was it rejected/paused?
How did you decide on the ‘stop immediately when touching the pyramid’ rule—was it to prevent exploits or reduce frustration?

open_questions.topic: Uninitialized stack value: debugging practices on N64-era-style codebases
open_questions.context: A random stack value caused major instability until identified.
questions: How did you detect it was stack garbage rather than bad math/parameters?
What tooling/logging do you rely on in this decomp-based workflow to catch uninitialized data?
How often do bugs like this appear when mixing decomp code, new features, and toolchains?

open_questions.topic: Demo readiness and console validation plan
open_questions.context: Kaze says the demo is done and N64 bugs are fixed, but he hasn’t fully tested the demo on console yet and plans a playthrough test video.
questions: What’s your definition of ‘done’ for the demo—content lock, performance lock, bug threshold?
What remains in the console test pass (crashes, memory, timing, controller edge cases)?
How do you triage emulator-only bugs (e.g., Glide) vs real-hardware issues?

open_questions.topic: Fast64 limitations and the decision not to hand-write display lists
open_questions.context: He avoids adding more mipmap levels because Fast64 exports only two and manual display-list edits would slow iteration.
questions: How much do tool limitations (Fast64) shape art direction and level complexity?
Have you considered building internal tooling or patches to Fast64 for mipmap support?
What are the biggest iteration bottlenecks in your current asset pipeline?

open_questions.context: Kaze notes F3DEX3 is now in the game, helping performance, with mentions of occlusion plane/triangle strips; he says the project is now RSP-bottlenecked.
questions: What specific gains did F3DEX3 deliver (FPS, draw distance, triangle budgets)?
What new design/level ambitions became possible after the performance uplift?
What does ‘RSP-bottlenecked’ mean in practice for RTYI content targets, and how do you optimize around it?

open_questions.context: The course is described as multi-biome with deserts/pyramids, mountains with ‘styrofoam,’ castle, and grasslands; name is not finalized.
questions: What’s the narrative/theme rationale for combining these biomes into one course?
How do you ensure the course still feels coherent and readable despite biome shifts?
What does the final name need to communicate—tone, craft motif, Yoshi’s Island reference?

open_questions.topic: NPC presentation: ‘mechanical’ Toad voice and star dispense animation
open_questions.context: Kaze experiments with making Toad’s dialogue sound ‘mechanical’ and notes the need for an animation when giving a star.
questions: What’s the intended emotional tone of NPCs in RTYI—cozy, funny, uncanny, storybook?
Will NPC voice/text styling vary by biome/theme?
Who is responsible for the final NPC animations and dialogue pass, and what’s the pipeline?

open_questions.topic: Cannon input timing bug (pressing A on frame 1)
open_questions.context: He identifies a reproducible bug triggered by immediate input after cannon exit.
questions: Is this a vanilla SM64 behavior or introduced by RTYI changes (custom cannon logic, new states)?
Will you fix it in code (state gating) or design around it (input lockout window)?
Are there other first-frame input edge cases (A, B, stick) in your custom movement/actions?

open_questions.topic: Rubber-band slingshot: final animation ownership and sound design
open_questions.context: Kaze gets a smooth base but notes he’s not the animator and that sound effects are still missing; the slingshot still needs to actually fling Mario (functionality not completed in this stream).
questions: Who will finalize the rubber-band animation and how many variations are planned (tension levels, failure states)?
What’s the final gameplay: does it launch Mario forward, upward, both, and is it player-timed?
How will audio sell the tactile craft materials (rubber snap, paper rustle, cardboard thud)?

open_questions.topic: Project-after-project: moving from ROM hack to an original game
open_questions.context: Kaze states he plans to make his own game after the hack, likely in Unreal Engine 5, possibly a 3D platformer.
questions: How has building RTYI on N64 constraints shaped what you want to do next creatively?
What parts of RTYI’s pipeline/tech do you want to carry into an original project (movement feel, level design approach, performance discipline)?
Will RTYI serve as a portfolio/vertical slice for a future independent studio effort?
